title: CTRL0000050985 - Transcribed Interview of Janet West Buhler, (February 28, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 11:04 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So let's go on the record at 11:04 a.m.
This is a transcribed interview of Ms. Janet Buhler conducted by
the House Select Committee to investigate the January 6th attack on the United States
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
This will be a staff-led interview.
Members, of course, may choose to ask
I don't see anybody who has joined so far.
So in the room today are myself,
At this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
Counsel for Ms. Buhler, Brett Tolman, T-o-1-m-a-n.
Thank you very much, Mr. Tolman.
So as noted, there is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview,
so please wait until each question is completed before you begin your next response, and
we will try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head,
so it is important that you answer each question with an audible verbal response.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
If you do not know the answer,
There are a couple of things I just want to cover with you before we get into the
So, first, it is important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
Similarly, if at any point you need to discuss something with your attorney in
private, please let us know, and we will take a break so you can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath.
But because this is a formal
congressional investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the
same as if you were speaking with the FBI or DOJ.
It is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
interview, providing false information could result in criminal penalties for false
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we
including the prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us,
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
with the select committee in this investigation.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and the DOJ is not a partner
The subcommittee also is not a party to your criminal case and is not agreeing to
submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representation
whether, if you tell the judge you met with us, that the judge will be more favorable to
Fifth, we have agreed with your attorney not to share the substance of what you
say with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing, but there are two possible
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement was
unaware of, or if we had reason to believe you lied during this interview, then we would
be obligated to tell DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement agency.
And, if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that that may
prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with
your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility.
questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
And if the judge starts asking
Logistically, just let us know if you need any breaks or if you'd like to discuss
We're happy to go off the record for a little bit if you need
might be asking questions as this goes
So as I noted, myself and
If we're ever talking over each or you can't hear us or we're just not clear, please
let us know and we'll repeat the question.
So that does all make sense to you, Ms. Buhler?
And with that, we'll get started with a little bit about your background.
I live in -- near Salt Lake City, Utah.
And how long have you lived there?
Were you born and raised in Utah or --
Where did you -- where were you born?
Well, I was born in Utah, just like in a clinic, but I was always raised
And what is your educational background?
I have a degree in fashion design from Brigham Young University, and I am
one credit short of a degree in piano performance from the University of Utah.
So what do you do for a living now?
So I teach piano and violin lessons and -- well, I used
to teach fashion at the college until I was fired for January 6th.
So now we're going to get into some more questions about, as you just noted,
January 6th, and the lead-up to it.
In general, how would you describe your level of political engagement
So when did you start getting engaged in political events?
Or when did you start really following politics?
Well, I mean, I just watch whatever is on the news.
know if that's what you mean or --
When were you -- so you said you were not
really involved politically during President Trump's term, but did you pay close attention
If you -- when you say "involved," do you mean, like, participating in,
like -- like, I don't know, a candidate's campaign or something like that, or do you just
mean, like, watching news or -- I'm not sure what you mean by "involved."
Did you go to any rallies during President Trump's term?
And then -- but did you follow politics closely during President
Trump's term on the news or otherwise?
I guess then there are two parts to the
in the sense of being part of a campaign or working for anyone in office, correct?
First, I think you answered -- and correct me if I'm wrong -- you were not involved
My husband is -- like, watches a lot more than I
Just like whenever the TV would be on, I would watch basically.
Did you ever read print publications about political news?
Like, we don't -- I mean, so we don't subscribe to a newspaper or anything
subscribed to any even email newsletters or anything.
I guess every once in a while I do.
Well, during his Presidency, I don't think I
whatever -- or listening to the radio, things like that.
So I have -- when I was on Facebook I had, you know, because I have friends
And was it local or national news?
Did you follow political news on social media ever?
So what they would post, I would look at.
say -- I'm just trying to remember back that far.
I mean, other than that, not really.
Did you follow any other social media sites?
list of them, and if yes, we'll go into it.
Do you also have a Twitter?
And I'm going to go through a
You said you don't have Twitter now.
I missed the whole Twitter thing.
Just want to make sure that's what it was.
So I'll go through a list, so just bear with me.
of any of them, just say you were not engaged.
Did you use Parler back in 2020?
I think I was on Parler for a minute, yeah.
And was that right before or after the election, do you remember?
I mean, there was -- it was political, I would say.
Do you remember what you followed on Parler?
As far as who it was --
It's okay if you can't remember exactly.
Would you say that you got a lot of information about
President Trump or about other political events on Parler?
I mean, there was a lot of talk about, gosh, all kinds of things, you know,
from the election to just other political figures.
Just like a variety of just politics, I guess.
Would you say you relied on Parler as a source more than the local news or
Oh, no, I didn't rely on Parler at all.
I mean, it was just more of, like,
Like, I want to -- I kind of like to compare what I saw on the news to what
was said on Parler, just, like, try to make my own opinion about it.
Telegram, I didn't start until -- because, you know, Parler, like, died.
was after that, that I heard about Telegram.
So that was in -- later, January 2021.
So you didn't use Telegram before?
I think I did create an account on there, but I never used it.
I don't know what that is.
And did you follow President Trump specifically on any of those social media
So right after the 2020 election, did you have any concerns about
Well, I was just concerned because the election went differently than other
Just usually we knew by, like, the end of that day, the election day, like, who
the winner was, but it, like, went on for weeks.
that was, like, they couldn't -- it took weeks for them to finish counting.
thought that was a little odd.
And even in Utah, we had a House race
Would you say that your concerns rose to the level that you thought the
election was stolen from former President Trump?
I don't know that I would say stolen, but just I'm like -- I was concerned
I would've liked, you know, some more investigation, just -- but I wouldn't say
that I think that it's stolen.
But I just kind of have, you know, just questions.
Do you remember precisely when you started to feel that way?
I know you mentioned the length of time that it took.
But was there, like, a moment
I guess, like, the next morning after the election, it was like, "Oh, they're not
done counting yet, huh," you know.
like, "I can't believe they're not done counting," like, it just kind of got, like, just more
And then so from then, like, every day would be,
Do you remember seeing messages on Facebook or Parler in the days before the
election about the possibility of the election being stolen?
Well, I mean, I think we've all seen messages like that.
Do you think that played into any of your concerns?
Because you never know about him, like, whether he's saying
something that's really overexaggerated or not.
What about other political figures or people like Rudy Giuliani or
someone else who before the election was talking about that?
Just like trying to figure out in the days before the election, did you
see any messaging that might've contributed to your concerns after the election?
Oh, not before the election, no.
So then after the election, did you start getting involved in any
activities related to alleged voter fraud or election insecurities?
Ms. Buhler, I just wanted to go back.
President Trump talking about possible issues with the election.
saying that might've stood out in your mind?
Well, I mean, this was after the election.
And, oh, gosh, I guess I don't
remember exactly what he said, but he's always, even now, still saying it was rigged or
Some kind of language like that.
And do you recall any terms such as Stop the Steal
I mean, like, a long -- a ways after that.
Like, I mostly heard that when I
went to the-- went to Washington, D.C., is when I really heard most of that.
We'll get into that later then.
Just for the record, you didn't go to attend the November 14th rally in
So you said you did not participate in any rallies or activities following the
And not the December 12th rally in Washington, D.C.?
So then what really made you decide that you wanted to travel to Washington,
So this is mostly kind of like the dynamics of the family.
husband -- like, we're a blended family.
mean, I know him, but I wouldn't say I know him real well.
was like, you know, a really big Trump supporter.
And his daughter's husband -- and, you know, I
before the rally -- and he said, "Listen, I really want to go.
And I don't have anybody to
And out of the idea of, like, creating better relationships in the family, like, that's
why I went, because I -- he really wanted to go.
And he's the one that, like, doesn't, what, blend well in the family, like, he
doesn't -- like, not everybody gets along with him.
So I just thought, okay, this will be a good way to kind of bond with him and, like,
bring the family closer together, that kind of thing.
Were you surprised that he called you?
I was kind of surprised, yeah.
Because I wouldn't say we're close.
And so will you go with me?"
And he called me -- I mean, it was, like, 2 days before the rally, maybe 3 days
So I was kind of, like, well, that's really soon.
Why did -- why would you say you weren't close?
Well, so this is her, like, sixth husband, like, he's pretty new to the family.
What about your relationship made you think you were not
And, you know, you just were like, well, is this going to last?
should I put into this relationship because she might divorce him?
Well, trying to think when they got married, because they got married after
So how long did you know him, I guess?
Do you know if he reached out to anyone else in your family to go
Did your husband talk about it at all?
Talk about going with your, I guess, stepson-in-law.
About me going with the stepson-in-law?
Did he talk about going with his son-in-law to Washington, D.C., on January 6th?
Oh, my husband didn't -- he never was invited or never said he wanted to go
She -- what I understood is that she had work, like -- I don't
know if she would've gone or not if she could have.
Did you ever speak with your son-in-law about political issues?
So before the election, probably not.
I think it was more after the election
that, you know -- which we don't see them that much.
So he -- I might've seen him
twice between, like, November 3rd and January 6th, like at Christmas, I think we saw
them, and maybe one other time.
And, I mean, I don't make a habit of calling them on
So, I mean, it would just have been, like, within family get-togethers where, you
know -- I mean, I knew he was, like, a Trump supporter.
didn't know how deep, like, how, you know, deep his support was at all.
I mean, I did know that.
Did you talk at all about Washington, D.C., when you saw him at
I -- gosh, I just don't remember.
Do you remember seeing any tweets or social media messaging about
President Trump around that time about inviting his supporters to Washington, D.C., for
a, quote/unquote, wild sort of rally?
I do remember, I mean, hearing that there was going to be a rally, for sure.
Yeah, I think -- yeah, yeah, yeah, because that's pretty close to January,
Did you follow your stepson-in-law on social media apps?
So around Christmas you knew there would be a rally?
So did he ever explain to you why he called you to go with him to
I'm a person that likes to travel, so I think -- and we've had, like, you know,
where I've never -- up until that time, I've never had any kind of disagreement with him or
any kind of, you know, bad interaction with him.
So, you know, it's been a very, what,
So that may be why he called me.
But had you two ever taken a trip together before?
Do you -- was he aware that you also -- I'm assuming he had concerns about
So was he aware that you also had concerns about the election?
And do you think that that played into his decision to ask you to go with
Were there other people -- did other people in your family share similar
I'm sure we probably talked about that at some point.
concerns, or was it mostly the two of you?
I would say our family is kind of divided, very divided on politics.
mean, there are some that are more on the conservative side and some on the more
And that's in my -- within my husband's children.
So that's probably why, because I would -- I would say I'm more conservative, so
that's why he would have talked to me.
And, like, other people in the family, like, could not have even afforded to go,
couldn't have bought an airline ticket.
So that's another thing, is he knew that I could.
So was it -- you said 3 days before.
decided to go to Washington, D.C., or right around there?
Yeah, I would say it was on, like, Sunday before.
For information about January 6th, since you said you were aware of
it, but were you relying on your stepson-in-law for information about what would
happen, or were you looking on social media?
So at that point when he said he wanted to go, I wanted to -- I remember
getting on VouTube, and I saw some, like -- follow this sort of religious guy that talks
people that were going to meet up there.
good, to kind of meet with that group.
And he said that his -- he was going to have a group of
And I saw that, and I thought that would be
Do you remember the name of the group or the social media site
This is, like, Professor Toto, he calls himself.
He's -- oh, he calls himself Great -- Great Harvest Ministries, I think.
And where would they -- where were they meeting up?
Do you mind me asking what kind of religion or religious group?
in a bus to Washington, D.C.?
It was just, like, they had a meeting point, and they were saying, you
know, come meet at this point.
Well, see, that's the thing, is since I've never been to Washington, D.C.,, I
could kind of generally, like, know somewhere near the monument.
And so that's what I wanted to do.
Was there any other information you were getting about the day
Did you ever end up meeting up with that group?
No, because my son-in-law did not want to.
And was that a disagreement you had before you left?
Well, he agreed to it before we left, but then when we got there, he said, "I
I think we'll get back to that in a little bit.
But just to close the loop on the
social media stuff, were you getting news about January 6th from Parler?
Do you remember any specific messaging or rhetoric?
So I'm one of those people that's an observer, so I don't -- I didn't ever post
I just was, like, watching what was going on.
Well, what do you remember observing?
I think just -- it was mostly people saying that they were going.
just -- I honestly just don't even remember.
It's just been that -- and I can't -- I mean, I
So I have no -- I just don't remember at all.
Do you remember people talking about taking a bus to Washington, D.C.?
I'll ask maybe a couple questions that might help.
How about anyone talking or using the word "caravan"?
And do you remember if there were any specific accounts that
you noticed were organizing people to go to January 6th?
So when did you end up leaving Washington, D.C.?
So it was hard to find a flight that went direct, so we left Tuesday morning.
What time did you arrive in D.C.?
And it was just you and your stepson-in-law traveling together?
Do you remember where it was -- oh, sorry.
For the record, you nodded "yes" to
-- it was just you and your stepson-in-law?
Where in Washington, D.C., did you end up staying?
I think it's called the Row Hotel, the Row.
I don't know what you mean by that.
Yeah, it was in Washington, D.C., I believe.
Was it in Washington, D.C., itself or was it in Maryland or Virginia?
And I know you didn't end up meeting up with the Great
Harvest -- sorry if I got that wrong -- Great Harvest group.
But did you meet up with
anybody else when you were here?
Did you expect any violence at January 6th?
But then I guess what was really your goal?
say yes to coming to Washington, D.C.?
What did you want to do when you were here?
friend of ours has been -- had been to two rallies and she said, "Oh, yeah, that they're
really great, they're really friendly, the people are great."
So I've -- like I said, I've never been to a rally before.
And, you know, a lot of people in Utah and friends that we know, a
And she did not end up going.
And -- sorry, what was your question?
So she made it sound like a
It was, what were you -- like, what was your goal in coming to
So, again, I wanted to support my son-in-law.
been to Washington, D.C., and I thought this would be a good time to go.
wanted to be part of the group.
Like, the entire -- the rally, part of the entire.
And why was it important to be part of the group?
I just wanted to get, like, maybe a perspective outside of my local area, to
just kind of get a feel, like, you know, because Utah's a pretty conservative place.
thought here's a chance to get a perspective from, you know, other parts of the country,
see other people there from different areas, see if they have concerns, how concerned
Like, I was just trying to figure out really -- you know, because I questioned myself
at the time, was I overly concerned, was I being swayed by, you know, things I saw in the
Like, I just wanted to get a sense of really what was going on.
So did you expect people who attended the rally not to be concerned about
No, I did expect them to be concerned.
But you said you were looking for different perspectives.
to figure out, what were those different perspectives?
the Presidential election, or did they feel like it was their other elections, you know, their
Well, I don't mean perspective as not concerned.
Like what did they feel like's going on in their State?
Was there talk of stolen local elections too?
So is it fair to say then, that in addition to being there to build a
relationship with your son-in-law, you also wanted to be part of the group raising a voice
So you mentioned earlier that you weren't expecting violence or anything.
you recall seeing messages on line or through the President or anything about, like,
I mean, it's -- I would think that would seem unsafe if it was
I mean, I'm not that kind of a person that can handle that.
So then you arrived in D.C., in the evening January 5th.
rallies in Washington, D.C., on January 5th?
By the time we got to our hotel and ate something it was, like, 9, 9
And then in the morning what did you do?
Well, so my stepson-in-law wanted to go early.
7:30 in the lobby and then make our way to the -- Ellipse?
kind of just went with his plan.
So he wanted to meet at
And that's when you had expected to meet up with this group?
I expected that we would make our way there, and then I
would -- because I know that they weren't meeting until, like, maybe 10 or something.
Were you still in contact with this group, or were you just following?
Oh, I never was in contact with them.
I was just hoping to, like, meet, meet
Were there any speakers at the rally you were particularly
Well, I didn't really know who was speaking, except I knew Trump was
And when you were in the crowd, did you have conversations with other
And what were people talking about?
I mean, it was -- it was very friendly, and, I mean, it was, like, you know,
"Hey, where are you from?" and, you know, just talking about things like that.
then, I mean, we were all just waiting, really, for it to start.
to people, but I don't, like, remember the specifics of our conversations.
Did you see people dressed up in military fatigues, with, like,
So what time did you actually get to the Ellipse?
Well, we left our hotel at 7:30.
We -- so when we went to the lobby, there was -- there were two other men
Did you take the train there?
there who said that they were going down to the rally -- and they were from
Michigan -- and they said, "Let's share an Uber together."
And I also might've missed this.
that when you arrived to D.C.,?
And you didn't go to any of the rallies on January 5th?
So you get to the Ellipse.
What was the process for actually getting in?
you in the inside part of the Ellipse, or were you out by the Washington Monument?
We were on the outer perimeter of that.
And were you near the Washington Monument, or where were you on the
So we thought about going in the perimeter but then there was, like, a really
long line, and, like, you had to go through, like, a security thing.
like we didn't want to do that.
So we just were kind of
And so we stood -- there was, like -- there were some speakers.
And then my son-in-law got a little impatient and he wanted to walk around.
then we ended up walking right up by the monument and just kind of -- I think he wanted
to find a better place to be able to see.
But then it was really cold.
So then the, you know, more separated from people
you were, then the more cold it was.
kind of came back down closer, back by the speaker again.
close because people had filled in.
So then we kind of walked around there and then
And I guess I missed this too.
But then we couldn't get as
What was the significance of coming to D.C.,
Like, why was January 6th the date that you feel like folks were coming
Well, I mean, they were coming for the rally, so --
on in Congress that people came to D.C., for?
Do you think the rally and folks came to D.C., for the
You don't think there was any proceedings going
Was that in the back of your mind when you came to
In the back of my mind, I wanted Congress to understand, like, how many
people were there that were concerned about the election.
just wanted to be part of that, like, visibility of how many people.
But were you tracking that January 6th was the actual date that Congress
Oh, yeah, I knew that that was the --
So that was part of the reason why you were willing to come to D.C.,
Just to be part of the whole thing.
Like, it was, like, the whole picture.
I wouldn't say that it was because of
I'm just saying part of that picture was the fact that Congress was
Janet, was the certification of the vote why you went to Congress -- went to D.C.,?
Like, I wanted to go to the rally.
my -- that was the thing I wanted to go to.
was coming to go to the rally.
I mean, it was just part of the day.
And, obviously, you knew there were others that were probably
Thank you, Mr. Tolman, for that.
So did you hear others in the crowd that weren't there really for the rally, that
were just there for the certification?
I think that became obvious later when Trump was speaking.
then some people started saying, "They're about to vote."
could see who was concerned about that, because people started just, like, leaving.
And then I feel like then you
I'll turn it over t o - Thank you.
Would you say a lot of people there were talking about certification?
I mean, it was just a general topic of the day because it was part of the day.
But were people talking about trying to stop certification?
Did anyone talk about Stop the Steal?
Not that I -- not anyone I was talking to.
That was kind of just a general, like, chant that was happening during the
Like, people would just start saying it.
How did you take the meaning of Stop the Steal?
Well, I didn't take it as, like, a thing that would happen that day.
thought it was a general, like, process thing that people were talking about, like, over
Because I had seen -- like, I saw the press conference with, you know, Giuliani and
Sidney Powell and that press conference where they were talking about lawsuits and
process and that it would be sorted out that way in the courts.
To me, that's what I thought Stop the Steal was, was that, like, legal
Weren't those lawsuits specifically aimed at trying to show that President
Trump should be the electoral college winner?
Well, I thought those lawsuits were to, like, find out in a legal way whether
that there was anything to those claims.
When you said you thought Stop the Steal was a long-term process, do you mean
Let me be a little clearer.
past President Biden's inauguration, like, a political movement in the long-term, or did
you mean the lawsuits, the short-term?
I mean -- no, it can't be a short-term.
But these lawsuits were aimed at keeping President Trump in office,
I thought they were more for, like, just finding out the evidence.
What did Mr. Giuliani -- or what do you remember Mr. Giuliani and
Ms. Powell saying about that evidence?
Just that there were questions about all kinds of things, like, from, like,
the -- I guess at that time they were talking about the vote count, the counting machines
And I'll tie this back to January 6th and Stop the Steal.
about Stop the Steal in the sense of President Trump won the election?
You know, if I look back, you know, what I think in my mind is different than
what other people think in their mind.
probably what they were thinking, is let's stop it today.
So, you know, now I can look back and say that's
I didn't mean to ask you to read their minds.
In terms of what you were hearing, were people talking about Stop the Steal in
the sense of President Trump is our President and needs to be re-inaugurated?
I mean, I don't think so, like, not in the group that I was around.
I guess, were you expecting, like, a big reveal of some sort from
President Trump during the rally on January 6th?
I was expecting that he might have had something different to say.
Did he say anything of that nature, do you remember?
Anything different than what I'd heard before?
Did he -- you said you were expecting something new just now.
anything new on January 6th about the election?
And what was your, I guess, response to that?
How did you feel after you
And so then I thought, well, he'll probably, like -- maybe he's leading up to it
and it just seemed to be, like, he wasn't going to say anything new.
Well, I mean, when he started talking, you know, I just thought, well, he's
But then as he went on, so, you know, it was going on for a long time,
So we've heard from other witnesses that they were -- I mean -- and I'm
quoting them -- disappointed that they didn't learn anything new from President Trump's
I guess that's what I'm trying to get at.
no feelings after you didn't learn anything new?
then it's just the same old thing."
They tell you they're going to do something or say something, and
So, kind of cynical that way, because I just thought, "Oh, well, that's a
So I wouldn't say I was disappointed, but I was not surprised either.
Were you disappointed, or did you have
So I guess then do you remember President Trump saying anything about
Was it marching or walking, I don't know.
And did you plan on marching to the Capitol before going to the
Did he march in part because of President Trump's speech?
You know, I'm not sure why.
And what was your reaction when he said that?
Well, I was just, like, "Well, okay."
I thought we were just going to go for the rally and just stay
So did you decide to march, in part, because of President Trump's
But, you know, I just remember standing
And then he said, "Come on, let's go."
just -- I -- and I said to him, I said, "I want to try to find that group that I want to meet up
And he said, "No, come on, let's go."
Did you think that President Trump was going to march or
be at the Capitol that day?
Well, I mean, I think he suggested that he was going to do that, but in my
mind I'm thinking, how could he do that?
